ground_truth: Merrill stares wearily up the staircase, climbing the first two steps, and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen, and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it. Graham hurries down some stairs into the gloomy basement and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door, his hands pushing against it, with its olive green paint peeling. Graham looks down at the doorknob, grabs it as it starts to turn, and holds it tight with both hands, resting his head on the door. Merrill spots a pickaxe, and as he yanks it off a high shelf, he smashes the light bulb, plunging the basement into darkness. Morgan turns on a torch, stares down into its bright beam before looking around, and points it at the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it, the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob, and Graham turns to put his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam. Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the basement, starts to walk past a cluttered workbench, and the light falls on Bo, crouched on the floor, who waves lamely at Morgan. Merrill finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the basement, illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and tunes the dial on the front. They go around to face the door, and Graham pushes his hand against the door lit by Morgan's torch. He then turns to face the others, the pickaxe holds in place as the doors hit, and Graham stares thoughtfully at the door. Morgan sets the white-headed silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father. Merrill walks over to Graham, and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions, working their way around the rough stone walls, passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg. They come towards each other again, their torch beams picking up the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him, stunned, as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son, and as he runs away from the coal chute, he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs, poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Merrill gazes wearily up the stairway, ascending the first two steps, and looks in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the corridor into the kitchen, and Morgan's terrified eyes concentrate on the gap at the bottom of the front entrance as green gray fingers emerge underneath it. Graham rushes down some stairs into the gloomy cellar and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door, his hands pushing against it, with its olive green paint peeling. Graham looks down at the knob, grips it as it starts to rotate, and holds it tight with both hands, resting his head on the door. Merrill spots a pickaxe, and as he yanks it off a high shelf, he shatters the light bulb, plunging the cellar into darkness. Morgan switches on a torch, stares down into its bright beam before looking around, and points it at the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it, the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the knob, and Graham turns to place his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam. Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the cellar, starts to walk by a cluttered workbench, and the light falls on Bo, crouched on the floor, who waves weakly at Morgan. Merrill finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the cellar, illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and tunes the dial on the front. They go around to face the door, and Graham presses his hand against the door illuminated by Morgan's torch. He then turns to face the others, the pickaxe holds in place as the doors are hit, and Graham gazes thoughtfully at the door. Morgan places the white-headed silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father. Merrill walks over to Graham, and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions, working their way around the rough stone walls, passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg. They come towards each other again, their torch beams picking up the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and gaze at him, stunned, as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son, and as he runs away from the coal chute, he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's limbs, poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Merrill stares wearily up the staircase, the first two steps are climbed by him, and horror grips him as the unsecured hatch door in the attic is gazed at by him. The children are pulled down the hallway into the kitchen by Merrill and Graham, and Morgan focuses his terrified eyes on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers are appearing underneath it. Some stairs are hurried down by Graham into the gloomy basement and the door is slammed shut by him. Suddenly he turns and the door is pressed against by his ear, the hands of Graham are pushing against it, with its olive green paint peeling. The doorknob is looked down at by Graham, and it is grabbed by him as it starts to turn, and it is held tight with both hands while his head rests on the door. A pickaxe is spotted by Merrill, and a high shelf is used by him to yank it off, causing the light bulb to be smashed, plunging the basement into darkness. A torch is turned on by Morgan, its bright beam is stared down into before looking around, and the door is pointed at by him. Hard is pushed against it by Graham and Merrill, the pickaxe is now firmly wedged under the doorknob, and his eyes are shielded from the bright torch beam as the door is turned against by Graham. The torch beam is slowly directed around the basement by Morgan, a cluttered workbench is started to be walked past, and Bo, crouched on the floor, is illuminated by the light, who waves lamely at Morgan. Another flashlight is found by Merrill and its beam is directed around the walls of the basement, old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and disordered clatter are illuminated. A dusty old radio is spotted on one shelf by him, and the dial on the front is tuned by him. They go around to face the door, and the hand of Graham is pushed against the door lit by Morgan's torch. He then turns to face the others, the pickaxe is held in place as the doors are hit, and the door is stared thoughtfully at by Graham. The white-headed silver torch is set on the ground by Morgan and it is rolled across to his father. Over to Graham walks Merrill, and slowly they move in different directions, working their way around the rough stone walls, passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg. Towards each other again they come, as the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it is picked up by their torch beams. Him is stared at by Merrill and Graham, stunned, as Morgan's throat is grabbed by a clawed hand poking through the grill. The torch is dropped by Graham as he rushes to rescue his son, and the torch is kicked by him as he runs away from the coal chute, around to pick out Bo's legs it rolls, poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Merrill wearily eyes the staircase, climbs two steps, and gazes in horror at the unsecured attic hatch door. He and Graham pull the children to the kitchen as Morgan sees green-gray fingers under the front door. Graham rushes into the basement, slams the door, and listens, gripping the peeling doorknob as it turns. Merrill grabs a pickaxe, smashes a light bulb, plunging them into darkness. Morgan turns on a torch, illuminating the door as he and Merrill brace it with the pickaxe. Morgan moves the light around, finding Bo crouched on the floor. Merrill uses a flashlight to examine old shelves with pickling jars, bowls, and more clutter, spotting a dusty radio. Graham leans against the door, holding it secure. Morgan rolls the torch to Graham, who moves along the stone walls with Merrill, passing a faded hanging and basket. They converge by the coal chute as a clawed hand grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch, rushing to save him, accidentally illuminating Bo's legs beneath her blue dress.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Merrill wearily climbs two steps and stares horrified at the attic's unsecured hatch. He and Graham drag the children to the kitchen as Morgan sees green-gray fingers under the front door. Graham rushes to the basement and slams the door, pressing ears and hands against its peeling olive paint, gripping the turning doorknob. Merrill grabs a pickaxe, accidentally smashes the light bulb, and Morgan's torch brightens the darkness. Graham and Merrill brace the door with the pickaxe while Morgan's torch finds Bo crouched on the floor. Merrill shines another flashlight on shelves holding jars, bowls, and clutter, spotting a dusty radio. Graham steadies the door and exchanges glances with the others as Morgan rolls his torch to him. Merrill and Graham explore the basement walls, passing hangings and baskets, meeting at a coal chute. They're stunned when a claw grabs Morgan's throat through the grill. Graham drops his torch rushing to help, accidentally revealing Bo's legs beneath her dress as she clings to the wall.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Merrill, feeling utterly exhausted, stares wearily up the daunting staircase, taking the first two steps with a heavy heart. He gazes in absolute horror at the unsecured hatch door that ominously hangs open in the attic above. Quickly, Merrill and Graham pull the frightened children down the hallway, leading them into the kitchen. Morgan's wide, terrified eyes are fixated on the gap at the bottom of the front door, where greenish-gray fingers ominously start to appear from underneath. With urgency, Graham hurries down a set of stairs into the dimly-lit, gloomy basement, slamming the door shut behind him with force. He suddenly turns and presses his ear tightly against the door, hands pushing firmly against the peeling olive green paint. Graham's gaze shifts downward to the doorknob as he grabs it urgently, feeling it begin to turn. Clutching it tightly with both hands, he rests his head wearily on the door. Meanwhile, Merrill spots a pickaxe and, yanking it aggressively off a high shelf, accidentally smashes the light bulb, plunging the entire basement into darkness. Morgan quickly turns on a torch, momentarily staring down into its bright beam before looking around the room. He soon directs the light towards the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it to secure it, with the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob. Graham then turns, pressing his back against the door to shield his eyes from the bright torchlight. Morgan methodically directs the beam of the torch around the basement, beginning to walk cautiously past a cluttered workbench. The light then falls upon Bo, who is crouched on the floor and waves feebly at Morgan. Merrill finds another flashlight, sweeping its beam around the basement walls. The light reveals old wooden shelves supporting a line of neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, and roller skates amidst disordered clatter. Spotting a dusty old radio on one shelf, he tunes the dial on its front. As they move to face the door, Graham places his hand against it, lit by Morgan's guiding torch. He turns to face the others, reassured that the pickaxe holds firmly in place as the door is struck. Graham stares thoughtfully at the door. Morgan gently sets the white-headed silver torch on the ground, rolling it across to his father. Merrill approaches Graham, and both Graham and Merrill move slowly in opposite directions, making their way around the rough stone walls. They pass a dry, faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging from another peg. Coming towards each other again, their torch beams illuminate the coal chute, with its rolling turning grill across it, and Morgan stands directly in front of it. Merrill and Graham halt and stare at him, utterly stunned, as a clawed hand suddenly pokes through the grill and clutches Morgan's throat. With urgency, Graham drops his torch and rushes to rescue his son. As he runs back from the coal chute, his foot inadvertently kicks the torch, which rolls around, casting light on Bo's legs. Her legs are sticking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself firmly up against the wall in sheer panic.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Merrill, feeling utterly drained and completely exhausted, stares wearily and with great reluctance up the daunting and intimidating staircase, taking the first two steps with a heavy heart full of dread. He gazes in absolute horror and shock at the unsecured hatch door that ominously hangs open in the attic above, a sight that fills him with unease. Quickly and with determined urgency, Merrill and Graham pull the frightened and bewildered children down the dim hallway, leading them into the kitchen with haste. Morgan's wide, terrified eyes are fixated and glued on the narrow gap at the bottom of the front door, where menacing, greenish-gray fingers ominously start to appear from underneath, casting a shadow of fear. With a sense of urgency, Graham hurries rapidly down a set of stairs into the dimly-lit, gloomy basement, slamming the door shut behind him with force and determination. He suddenly turns swiftly and presses his ear tightly against the door, hands pushing firmly against the peeling olive green paint. Graham's gaze shifts downward to the doorknob as he grabs it urgently, feeling it begin to turn ominously. Clutching it tightly with both hands, he rests his head wearily on the door, trying to prevent it from opening. Meanwhile, Merrill spots a pickaxe and, yanking it aggressively off a high shelf, accidentally smashes the light bulb, plunging the entire basement into darkness. Morgan quickly turns on a torch, momentarily staring down into its bright beam before looking around the room. He soon directs the light towards the door, illuminating their immediate surroundings. Graham and Merrill push hard against it to secure it, with the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob, adding a layer of security. Graham then turns, pressing his back against the door to shield his eyes from the bright torchlight. Morgan methodically directs the beam of the torch around the basement, beginning to walk cautiously past a cluttered workbench filled with tools. The light then falls upon Bo, who is crouched on the floor and waves feebly at Morgan, her expression showing relief and anxiety. Merrill finds another flashlight, sweeping its beam around the basement walls. The light reveals old wooden shelves supporting a line of neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, and roller skates amidst disordered clatter. Spotting a dusty old radio on one shelf, he tunes the dial on its front in an attempt to hear any signs of life. As they move to face the door, Graham places his hand against it, lit by Morgan's guiding torch. He turns to face the others, reassured that the pickaxe holds firmly in place as the door is struck. Graham stares thoughtfully and intently at the door. Morgan gently sets the white-headed silver torch on the ground, rolling it across to his father. Merrill approaches Graham, and both Graham and Merrill move slowly in opposite directions, making their way around the rough stone walls. They pass by a dry, faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging from another peg, reminders of normalcy in a tense situation. Coming towards each other again, their torch beams illuminate the coal chute, with its rolling turning grill across it, and Morgan stands directly in front of it. Merrill and Graham halt and stare at him, utterly stunned and horrified, as a clawed hand suddenly pokes through the grill and clutches Morgan's throat. With urgency, Graham drops his torch and rushes to rescue his son. As he runs back from the coal chute, his foot inadvertently kicks the torch, which rolls around, casting light on Bo's legs. Her legs are sticking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself firmly up against the wall in sheer panic.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Merrill, standing at the base of the staircase, directs his weary gaze upward, taking a moment to absorb the sight before him. With a deep breath, he cautiously ascends the first two steps and comes to an abrupt halt as his eyes fixate in horror on the unsecured hatch door leading to the attic, its precariousness unsettling him. In an urgent response, Merrill and Graham swiftly shepherd the children down the hallway, their movements hurried as they guide the family into the safety of the kitchen. Meanwhile, Morgan's eyes widen with terror, zeroing in on the ominous gap at the bottom of the front door where green-gray fingers start to creep through, clawing at his already fragile sense of security. In a split second, Graham darts down a separate staircase into the dimly lit basement, frantically slamming the door shut behind him to cut off any immediate danger. He pivots quickly, pressing his ear flat against the door, his hands firmly applied against its rough surface, with the olive green paint flaking beneath his touch. As he peers downwards, Graham notices the doorknob begin to turn ominously, prompting him to grasp it tightly with both hands, desperately holding it stationary while resting his head for leverage against the door's cool exterior. Nearby, Merrill's eyes catch sight of a pickaxe hanging from a high shelf. With a determined yank, he retrieves the tool, unceremoniously smashing a light bulb in the process, casting the basement into sudden darkness and heightening the room's tense atmosphere. In the ensuing blackness, Morgan flicks on a torch, staring momentarily into its blindingly bright beam before sweeping it around the room. He directs the torch beam toward the door where Graham and Merrill are bracing themselves, and they both press with all their might against it, further securing the barrier by wedging the pickaxe under the doorknob. Graham then strategically positions himself with his back against the door, shielding his eyes from Morgan's glaring torchlight. Methodically, Morgan pans the torch beam around the packed basement, illuminating various items as he maneuvers past a cluttered workbench. The light lands on Bo, who is crouched low on the floor; she feebly waves at Morgan, acknowledging his presence in the dim surroundings. Across the room, Merrill discovers another flashlight, which he promptly uses to cast additional light along the basement’s rugged walls, revealing an array of old wooden shelves. The shelves hold neatly organized pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and an assortment of random clutter. Scanning the shelves, he spots a dusty old radio, adjusts the dial on its front, hoping to tune into some kind of signal. The group shifts to face the door, enveloped in the torchlight provided by Morgan. Graham presses his hand firmly against the door, feeling the resistance against the pickaxe holding it closed. He spins around to address the others, his expression thoughtful and tense. Observing this, Morgan places his white-headed silver torch on the ground, watching as it rolls gently across the floor to come to a stop near his father. As Merrill makes his way toward Graham, both begin to move methodically in differing directions, following the rough contour of the stone walls. Their journey takes them past an array of old artifacts, such as a dried and faded flowery decoration hanging from a hook, and a wire-framed basket anchored on another peg. Eventually, they reconvene, their paths merging as the torch beams reveal the coal chute with a rotating grill across it, now highlighted by Morgan's presence in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand frozen in shock as a clawed hand suddenly shoots through the grill and seizes Morgan’s throat in a vice-like grip. Reacting instinctively, Graham drops his torch and sprints toward his son, his movements frantic and urgent. In his rush away from the coal chute, he inadvertently kicks the torch, causing it to spin across the floor, ultimately illuminating Bo's legs, which are protruding from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses tightly against the wall, caught in the chaos of the moment.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Merrill, staring wearily up the staircase, is horrified by the unsecured attic hatch door. He and Graham quickly move the children into the kitchen, as Morgan's terrified gaze fixes on the emerging green-gray fingers under the front door. Graham rushes into the dark basement, slamming the door shut, and listens intently while holding the doorknob tightly as it begins to turn. Merrill grabs a pickaxe, accidentally shattering a light bulb and plunging the room into darkness. Morgan switches on a torch, illuminating the door while Graham and Merrill brace it with the pickaxe. Shielding his eyes, Graham leans against the door while Morgan directs the torchlight across the basement, revealing Bo crouched nearby. Merrill finds another flashlight, casting light on the cluttered shelves and a dusty radio, which he begins to tune. They inspect the basement, Graham ensuring the door remains secure as Morgan rolls the torch to him. Merrill and Graham explore opposite directions along the stone walls, their beams revealing a coal chute where Morgan stands. They are startled when a clawed hand grabs Morgan's throat through the grill. Graham drops his torch in a rush to rescue his son, inadvertently highlighting Bo's legs beneath her dress as she presses against the wall.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Merrill, exhausted from the day's tense events, stares wearily up the winding wooden staircase of their century-old farmhouse, climbing the first two creaking steps, and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic, a place rumored to be filled with forgotten relics of the past. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the dimly-lit hallway into the kitchen, and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the heavy, oak front door as green gray fingers, reminiscent of legends about creatures in rural folklore, appear underneath it. Graham hurries down some narrow stairs into the gloomy basement, a space originally designed for storing provisions in the colder months, and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door, his hands pushing against it, with its olive green paint peeling from years of exposure to the damp air. Graham looks down at the rusty doorknob, grabs it as it starts to turn, and holds it tight with both hands, resting his head on the door, feeling the coolness of its surface. Merrill spots a pickaxe, a tool from his grandfather’s old mining days, and as he yanks it off a high shelf, he accidentally smashes the light bulb, plunging the basement into darkness. Morgan turns on a torch, an antique that once belonged to Graham's late father, stares down into its bright beam before looking around, and points it at the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it, the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob, and Graham turns to put his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam. Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the basement, starts to walk past a cluttered workbench where Graham used to tinker with his inventions, and the light falls on Bo, crouched on the floor, who waves lamely at Morgan. Merrill finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the basement, illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots from family ski trips, roller skates, and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and cautiously tunes the dial on the front, hoping to catch any broadcast. They go around to face the door, and Graham pushes his hand against the door lit by Morgan's torch, feeling the vibrations from outside. He then turns to face the others, the pickaxe holds in place as the doors hit, and Graham stares thoughtfully at the door, assessing their precarious situation. Morgan sets the white-headed silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father, an heirloom from a past generation. Merrill walks over to Graham, and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions, working their way around the rough stone walls, passing a dry and faded flowery hanging, a relic from a forgotten era, on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg, used in the past for collecting eggs. They come towards each other again, their torch beams picking up the coal chute, once used to fuel the old furnace, with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him, stunned, as a clawed hand, eerily reminiscent of tales told by the elders, pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son, and as he runs away from the coal chute, he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs, poking out from beneath her silky blue dress, a hand-me-down from her mother, as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Merrill stares wearily up the staircase climbing the first two steps and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it. Graham hurries down some stairs into the gloomy basement and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door his hands pushing against it with its olive green paint peeling. Graham looks down at the doorknob grabs it as it starts to turn and holds it tight with both hands resting his head on the door. Merrill spots a pickaxe and as he yanks it off a high shelf he smashes the light bulb plunging the basement into darkness. Morgan turns on a torch stares down into its bright beam before looking around and points it at the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob and Graham turns to put his back against the door shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam. Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the basement starts to walk past a cluttered workbench and the light falls on. Bo crouched on the floor who waves lamely at Morgan. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. Merrill finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the basement illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatlyarranged pickling jars bowls ski boots roller skates and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and tunes the dial on the front. They go around to face the door and Graham pushes his hand against the door lit by Morgan's torch. He then turns to face the others. the pickaxe holds in place as the doors hit and Graham stares thoughtfully at the door. Morgan sets the whiteheaded silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father. Merrill walks over to Graham and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions working their way around the rough stone walls passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wireframed basket hanging on another peg. They come towards each other again their torch beams picking up the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him stunned as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son and as he runs away from the coal chute he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

Merrill and Graham pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it. test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Merrill stares wearily up the staircase climbing the first two steps and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it. Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him stunned as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat. Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son and as he runs away from the coal chute he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Jasper stares wearily up the staircase, climbing the first two steps, and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Jasper and Logan pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen, and Emily's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it. Logan hurries down some stairs into the gloomy basement and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door, his hands pushing against it, with its olive green paint peeling. Logan looks down at the doorknob, grabs it as it starts to turn, and holds it tight with both hands, resting his head on the door. Jasper spots a pickaxe, and as he yanks it off a high shelf, he smashes the light bulb, plunging the basement into darkness. Emily turns on a torch, stares down into its bright beam before looking around, and points it at the door. Logan and Jasper push hard against it, the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob, and Logan turns to put his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam. Emily slowly directs the torch beam around the basement, starts to walk past a cluttered workbench, and the light falls on Alex, crouched on the floor, who waves lamely at Emily. Jasper finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the basement, illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and tunes the dial on the front. They go around to face the door, and Logan pushes his hand against the door lit by Emily's torch. He then turns to face the others, the pickaxe holds in place as the doors hit, and Logan stares thoughtfully at the door. Emily sets the white-headed silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to her uncle. Jasper walks over to Logan, and Logan and Jasper move slowly in different directions, working their way around the rough stone walls, passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg. They come towards each other again, their torch beams picking up the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Emily standing in front of it. Jasper and Logan stand and stare at her, stunned, as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Emily's throat. Logan drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his niece, and as he runs away from the coal chute, he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Alex's legs, poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Merrill stares wearily up the ladder, climbing the first two rungs, and gazes in horror at the unsecured trap door in the loft. Merrill and Graham pull the children down the corridor into the pantry, and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the crack at the bottom of the side door as blue gray feathers appear underneath it. Graham hurries down some steps into the dim cellar and slams the door shut. He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door, his hands pushing against it, with its mustard yellow paint peeling. Graham looks down at the handle, grabs it as it starts to turn, and holds it tight with both hands, resting his head on the door. Merrill spots a broom, and as he yanks it off a high hook, he shatters the light fixture, plunging the cellar into darkness. Morgan activates a lantern, stares down into its bright glow before looking around, and points it at the door. Graham and Merrill push hard against it, the broom now firmly wedged under the handle, and Graham turns to put his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright lantern glow. Morgan slowly directs the lantern glow around the cellar, starts to walk past a cluttered desk, and the light falls on Bo, crouched on the floor, who waves limply at Morgan. Merrill finds another lamp and directs its glow around the walls of the cellar, illuminating old metal shelves supporting neatly-arranged canned goods, mugs, tennis shoes, rollerblades, and disordered clatter. He spots a dusty old clock on one shelf and adjusts the hand on the front. They go around to face the door, and Graham pushes his hand against the door lit by Morgan's lantern. He then turns to face the others, the broom holds in place as the doors hit, and Graham stares thoughtfully at the door. Morgan sets the white-headed silver lantern on the ground and rolls it across to his father. Merrill walks over to Graham, and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions, working their way around the rough concrete walls, passing a dry and faded floral apron hanging on a hook and a wire-framed hat hanging on another peg. They come towards each other again, their lantern beams picking up the coal chute with a spinning sliding panel across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him, stunned, as a scaled hand pokes through the panel and grabs Morgan's arm. Graham drops his lantern as he rushes to rescue his son, and as he runs away from the coal chute, he kicks the lantern which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs, poking out from beneath her silky yellow skirt as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Merrill glances wearily up the staircase, hopping onto the first two steps, and peers in confusion at the unsecured hatch door in the attic. Merrill and Graham drag the children down the hallway into the kitchen, and Morgan's terrified eyes track the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers slither underneath it. Graham rushes down some stairs into the gloomy basement and eases the door closed. He spins suddenly and rests his ear near the door, his hands leaning against it, with its olive green paint flaking. Graham glances down at the doorknob, seizes it as it begins to rotate, and clamps it tight with both hands, resting his forehead on the door. Merrill notices a pickaxe, and as he lifts it off a high shelf, he taps the light bulb, dimming the basement into shadows. Morgan switches on a torch, peers into its bright glow before glancing around, and directs it at the door. Graham and Merrill lean heavily against it, the pickaxe now securely braced under the doorknob, and Graham shifts to place his back against the door, shielding his eyes from the bright torch glow. Morgan slowly shifts the torch light around the basement, starts to stroll past a cluttered workbench, and the light lands on Bo, huddled on the floor, who nods weakly at Morgan. Merrill locates another flashlight and aims its beam around the walls of the basement, highlighting old wooden shelves supporting neatly-arranged pickling jars, bowls, ski boots, roller skates, and disordered clatter. He notices a dusty old radio on one shelf and fiddles with the dial on the front. They rotate to face the door, and Graham rests his hand against the door lit by Morgan's torch. He then turns to glance at the others, the pickaxe remains in place as the doors tremble, and Graham gazes thoughtfully at the door. Morgan places the white-headed silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father. Merrill approaches Graham, and Graham and Merrill drift slowly in different directions, maneuvering their way around the rough stone walls, bypassing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wire-framed basket hanging on another peg. They move towards each other again, their torch beams highlighting the coal chute with a rotating sliding grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it. Merrill and Graham stand and gaze at him, astonished, as a clawed hand darts through the grill and clasps Morgan's throat. Graham releases his torch as he dashes to save his son, and as he bolts away from the coal chute, he nudges the torch which rolls around to reveal Bo's legs, stretching out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The giraffe glances warily up the bridge, ascending the first two rungs, and looks in dread at the unsecured trap door in the loft. The giraffe and the rhino drag the kangaroos down the corridor into the cafeteria, and Kevin's panicked pupils focus on the gap at the bottom of the garage gate as purple orange toes emerge underneath it. The rhino rushes down some ladders into the dim cellar and slams the hatch closed. It pivots abruptly and presses its ear against the hatch, its paws pushing against it, with its mauve coat peeling. The rhino glances down at the lever, seizes it as it begins to rotate, and clutches it firmly with both paws, resting its ear against the hatch. The giraffe spots a spade, and as it tugs it off a tall rack, it shatters the chandelier, casting the cellar into shadows. Kevin flicks on a lantern, peers into its glowing stream before scanning the area, and directs it at the hatch. The rhino and the giraffe shove forcefully against it, the spade now securely lodged under the lever, and the rhino pivots to press its spine against the hatch, guarding its eyes from the glaring lantern glow. Kevin cautiously maneuvers the lantern glow around the cellar, begins to stroll past a cluttered desk, and the light lands on Reginald, huddled on the rug, who waves feebly at Kevin. The giraffe discovers another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the cellar, illuminating ancient iron racks supporting meticulously-aligned spice containers, teacups, ice skates, roller blades, and jumbled noise. It spies a dusty old walkie-talkie on one rack and adjusts the dial on the side. They circle to confront the hatch, and the rhino presses its paw against the hatch lit by Kevin's lantern. It then pivots to face the others, the spade holds in position as the hatches collide, and the rhino stares thoughtfully at the hatch. Kevin places the mint-headed bronze lantern on the tiles and rolls it over to its parent. The giraffe strolls over to the rhino, and the rhino and the giraffe move slowly in opposite directions, navigating their way along the harsh brick partitions, passing a parched and faded floral drape on a hook and a metal-framed crate hanging on another peg. They approach each other once more, their lantern beams highlighting the ash slide with a rotating shifting grate over it and Kevin standing in front of it. The giraffe and the rhino stand and gape at it, overwhelmed, as a taloned appendage pokes through the grate and grabs Kevin's collar. The rhino drops its lantern as it dashes to save its child, and as it bolts from the ash slide, it nudges the lantern which spins to reveal Reginald's limbs, peeking out from underneath her silky crimson robe as she presses herself against the facade.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Maggie glances curiously up the slide, hopping the first two rungs, and smiles in wonder at the locked trapdoor in the loft. Maggie and Greg steer the pets down the corridor into the dining room, and Max's curious gaze notices the crack at the top of the rear door as orange-yellow claws emerge above it. Greg creeps up some stairs into the bright attic and swings the door closed. He spins quickly and rests his chin against the door, his fingers pulling it inward, with its navy blue paint cracking. Greg peers up at the handle, lifts it as it ceases to rotate, and grips it gently with both arms, leaning his shoulder on the door. Maggie notices a broomstick, and as she pulls it off a low table, she taps the lantern, flooding the attic with light. Max switches off a lamp, glances up into its dim glow before peering around, and casts it toward the door. Greg and Maggie press lightly against it, the broomstick now gently placed above the handle, and Greg turns to place his elbow against the door, shading his eyes from the dim lamp glow. Max quickly swings the lamp glow around the attic, begins to tiptoe past a dusty bookshelf, and the light falls on Sam, crouched on the chair, who nods quietly at Max. Maggie uncovers an additional lantern and sweeps its glow around the corners of the attic, highlighting new metallic boxes containing randomly-placed painting equipment, jars, rollerblades, and assembled clutter. She uncovers a vintage new microphone on one table and dials the switch on the back. They circle to approach the door, and Greg drags his palm along the door highlighted by Max's lamp. He then twists to glance at the others, the broomstick maintains its position as the doors swing, and Greg peers curiously at the door. Max places the black-headed golden lamp on the floor and slides it over to his uncle. Maggie strolls over to Greg, and Greg and Maggie wander gradually in opposing paths, navigating around the smooth metal panels, bypassing a damp and bright sparkling curtain draped on a peg and a silver-plated basket dangling on another hook. They progress towards one another again, their lantern beams catching the canvas hatch with a sliding spinning cover across it and Max standing beside it. Maggie and Greg stand and smile at him, amazed, as a feathered wing stretches through the cover and brushes Max’s shoulder. Greg lifts his lamp as he dashes to assist his nephew, and as he sprints toward the canvas hatch, he taps the lamp which twirls around to illuminate Sam's arms, protruding from beneath her glossy red cloak as she supports herself up against the ceiling.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Merrill glances drowsily at the escalator, skipping the first two rungs, and peers in fascination at the unlatched trap door in the loft. Merrill and Graham drag the children along the corridor into the pantry, and Morgan's scared eyes concentrate on the slit at the base of the back window as blue orange toes sneak beneath it. Graham rushes up a ladder into the dim attic and swings the window shut. He spins abruptly and leans his nose against the window, his elbows pressing against it, with its mustard yellow trim flaking. Graham glances up at the curtain tie, grasps it as it begins to twist, and secures it tight with both elbows, leaning his shoulders on the window. Merrill notices a crowbar, and as he tugs it off a low cabinet, he knocks over the candle, enveloping the attic in shadows. Morgan activates a lantern, gazes into its dim glow before glancing around, and aims it at the window. Graham and Merrill shove forcefully against it, the crowbar now securely lodged beneath the curtain tie, and Graham pivots to rest his back against the window, shielding his face from the dim lantern glow. Morgan gradually swings the lantern glow around the attic, begins to tiptoe past a messy bookshelf, and the light lands on Bo, crouching on the ground, who gestures weakly at Morgan. Merrill finds another lamp and casts its glow around the beams of the attic, highlighting old metal brackets holding randomly-stacked cereal boxes, mugs, snowshoes, sleds, and jumbled rattle. He notices a dusty old cassette player on one bracket and fiddles with the knob on the side. They circle around to meet the window, and Graham presses his elbow against the window lit by Morgan's lantern. He then swivels to face the others, the crowbar holds in place as the windows rattle, and Graham gazes pensively at the window. Morgan places the yellow-beamed bronze lantern on the floor and spins it across to his father. Merrill strides over to Graham, and Graham and Merrill glide gently in opposite directions, navigating their way around the rough wooden beams, passing a damp and vibrant tapestry hanging on a nail and a metal-rimmed crate dangling from another hook. They move towards each other again, their lamp beams highlighting the coal stove with a spinning rotating grate across it and Morgan standing beside it. Merrill and Graham stand and gaze at him, bewildered, as a tentacled arm pushes through the grate and clutches Morgan's shoulder. Graham drops his lamp as he dashes to save his son, and as he scampers away from the coal stove, he nudges the lamp which spins around to illuminate Bo's arms, sticking out from her lacy red robe as she presses herself up against the beam.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Arlo glances skeptically at the ladder, hopping over the first two rungs, and surveys in disbelief the unsecured portal leading to the loft. Arlo and Finley drag the kittens through the corridor into the pantry, and Sawyer's frightened ears swivel towards the crevice at the base of the rear gate as purple speckled tentacles slither out from beneath it. Finley rushes up some steps into the dim attic and barricades the gate shut. He pivots abruptly and presses his forehead against the gate, his paws bracing against it, with its sapphire blue paint chipping. Finley gazes at the gatehandle, clenches it as it begins to twist, bolting it tight with both paws, leaning his forehead on the gate. Arlo notices a shovel, and as he pulls it down from a low rack, he shatters the lamp, plunging the attic into shadows. Sawyer flicks on a lantern, gazes deeply into its radiant ray before glancing around, and swings it towards the gate. Finley and Arlo brace firmly against it, the shovel now snugly jammed under the gatehandle, and Finley turns to lean his shoulder against the gate, shielding his face from the radiant lantern ray. Sawyer slowly aims the lantern ray around the attic, begins to wander past a jumbled dresser, and the light lands on Rae, crouched on the carpet, who flutters helplessly at Sawyer. Arlo snatches another lantern and aims its ray around the corners of the attic, highlighting ancient iron racks bearing haphazardly-organized jam jars, cups, hiking boots, and scattered debris. He notices a dusty ancient telephone on one rack and flips the switch on the side. They stroll around to face the gate, and Finley sets his paw against the gate lit by Sawyer's lantern. He then turns to face the others, the shovel holds in place as the gates strike, and Finley contemplates the gate. Sawyer places the golden-rimmed copper lantern on the floor and slides it across to his father. Arlo ambles over to Finley, and Finley and Arlo wander slowly in opposing paths, maneuvering their way around the rugged brick partitions, passing a damp and tattered floral drapery hanging on a loop and a wooden-framed chest suspended on another hook. They advance towards each other again, their lantern rays highlighting the coal shaft with a rotating sliding grate across it and Sawyer stationed before it. Arlo and Finley halt and gape at him, shocked, as a serrated tentacle thrusts through the grate and grips Sawyer's ear. Finley drops his lantern as he dashes to liberate his offspring, and as he sprints from the coal shaft, he bumps the lantern which spins around to illuminate Rae's feet, sticking out from beneath her velvety orange gown as she leans herself up against the corner.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Merrill and Graham face a tense situation as they usher their children into the basement to escape an intruding threat. Morgan notices ominous fingers under the front door, heightening the urgency. Graham secures the basement door, pushing against it as Merrill finds a pickaxe to bolster their defense, shattering the light and plunging them into darkness. Morgan's torch reveals Bo on the floor, while Merrill discovers a dusty radio among cluttered shelves. Graham and Merrill survey the basement, encountering a clawed hand through a grill that seizes Morgan's throat. Graham immediately rushes to save his son, accidentally illuminating Bo with his dropped torch, revealing her trying to stay safe against the wall.

on a hook and a wireframed basket hanging on another peg Graham and Merrill push hard against it the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob and Graham turns to put his back against the door shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the basement starts to walk past a cluttered workbench and the light falls on Merrill stares wearily up the staircase climbing the first two steps and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door his hands pushing against it with its olive green paint peeling

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: Merrill finds another flashlight and directs its beam around the walls of the basement illuminating old wooden shelves supporting neatlyarranged pickling jars bowls ski boots roller skates and disordered clatter He spots a dusty old radio on one shelf and tunes the dial on the front They go around to face the door and Graham pushes his hand against the door lit by Morgan's torch He then turns to face the others the pickaxe holds in place as the doors hit and Graham stares thoughtfully at the door Morgan sets the whiteheaded silver torch on the ground and rolls it across to his father Merrill walks over to Graham and Graham and Merrill move slowly in different directions working their way around the rough stone walls passing a dry and faded flowery hanging on a hook and a wireframed basket hanging on another peg They come towards each other again their torch beams picking up the coal chute with a rolling turning grill across it and Morgan standing in front of it Merrill and Graham stand and stare at him stunned as a clawed hand pokes through the grill and grabs Morgan's throat Graham drops his torch as he rushes to rescue his son and as he runs away from the coal chute he kicks the torch which rolls around to pick out Bo's legs poking out from beneath her silky blue dress as she presses herself up against the wall Merrill stares wearily up the staircase climbing the first two steps and gazes in horror at the unsecured hatch door in the attic Merrill and Graham pull the children down the hallway into the kitchen and Morgan's terrified eyes focus on the gap at the bottom of the front door as green gray fingers appear underneath it Graham hurries down some stairs into the gloomy basement and slams the door shut He turns suddenly and presses his ear against the door his hands pushing against it with its olive green paint peeling Graham looks down at the doorknob grabs it as it starts to turn and holds it tight with both hands resting his head on the door Merrill spots a pickaxe and as he yanks it off a high shelf he smashes the light bulb plunging the basement into darkness Morgan turns on a torch stares down into its bright beam before looking around and points it at the door Graham and Merrill push hard against it the pickaxe now firmly wedged under the doorknob and Graham turns to put his back against the door shielding his eyes from the bright torch beam Morgan slowly directs the torch beam around the basement starts to walk past a cluttered workbench and the light falls on Bo crouched on the floor who waves lamely at Morgan
